title: Albanese attends exclusive dinner with Trump ahead of APEC summit | ABC NEWS
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has attended a dinner with a select group of world leaders including US President Donald Trump at the Hilton hotel in South Korea's  ahead of the APEC summit.  Other attendees included Kiwi Prime Minister Christopher Luxon, Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney.  The US president is expected to meet Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the summit to discuss avoiding hefty tariffs and restrictions on rare earth exports. title: Australian faces lengthy US jail term after selling trade secrets to Russian broker | ABC NEWS
description: An Australian man has pleaded guilty in a Washington DC court to selling cybersecurity information to a Russian broker.  Peter Williams admitted to leaking eight trade secrets from his company, which is a subcontractor for the US Department of Defense, to a company which sells cyber exploit opportunities to the Kremlin.  The 39-year-old former Australian Signals Directorate (ASD) employee is now facing up to 20 years in jail. US Attorney-General Pam Bondi says the case signals that American national security is ‘not for sale’. title: Deadly round of Israeli strikes tests fragile ceasefire in Gaza | ABC NEWS
description: The United States maintains the ceasefire it brokered in Gaza is holding, despite the latest strikes by Israel to thwart what it claims was an imminent attack by Hamas. Gaza's health ministry says more than 100 people were killed in the strikes. Both sides continue to accuse each other of ceasefire violations, with Israel saying Hamas has staged the discovery of human remains in the search for dead hostages. title: Microsoft cloud service outage impacts airlines, airports and video games | ABC NEWS
description: Microsoft's cloud based Azure service has been impacted by an outage caused by a backend configuration change. The failure affected a wide range of cloud-based websites and services including Microsoft Office 365, Heathrow Airport, Alaska and Hawaiian Airlines, as well as XBox and Minecraft. It's the second outage involving a cloud computing service in a week. Issues with Amazon's AWS platform took down a broad range of online services, including social media, gaming, food delivery, streaming and financial platforms. title: Zelenskyy labels Kremlin a terrorist group after Russian strike on children’s hospital | ABC NEWS
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has labelled the Kremlin a terrorist organisation after a Russian strike on a children’s hospital in Ukraine’s southern city of Kherson.  Meanwhile, Moscow claims it has successfully trialled a nuclear-armed underwater drone, as Russian President Vladimir Putin flexes Russian military might.  US Vice-President JD Vance has doubled down on Washington’s recommendation that Kyiv cedes territory to reach an end to the war in Ukraine. title: Can the stolen jewels be recovered after Louvre heist arrests? | ABC NEWS
description: Two suspects arrested over the daring Louvre heist are set to be charged with theft and criminal conspiracy after partially confessing to the charges, according to French prosecutors. Four thieves broke into the world's most visited museum on October 19, exposing major gaps in the attraction's security. Police are still searching for two of the suspects and investigators say the stolen jewellery has not yet been recovered. title: Australian sunscreen maker at centre of recalls blocked by US regulator | ABC NEWS
description: Perth-based supplier Wild Child Laboratories has been blocked from exporting sunscreens to the United States for the past three years for breaching manufacturing standards. Despite that, the Australian Therapeutic Goods Administration has not prevented the company from supplying sunscreens for the Australian market. An international product testing expert has called on the TGA to release its own audit of products to reassure consumers. title: Easey Street Murders: The case against Perry Kouroumblis
description: The prosecution has detailed the graphic crime scene on Easey Street, on the first day of a committal hearing for alleged murderer Perry Kouroumblis.   Reporter Alexandra Alvaro joins Stephen Stockwell to talk through the events in court, including a legal battle over whether media could report on DNA evidence allegedly linking accused Perry Kouroumblis to the scene. Also, we answer your questions about this historic Melbourne case.   If you have any questions you'd like Alex or Stocky to answer in future episodes, please email thecaseof@abc.net.au (mailto:thecaseof@abc.net.au) .   The Case Of is the follow-up to the hit podcast Mushroom Case Daily, and all episodes of that show will remain available in the back catalogue of The Case Of.

title: Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim on how he's navigating Trump's tariffs | ABC NEWS
description: At the closing of this year’s ASEAN summit, Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim says while the US are tough negotiators, he can live with trade deals signed with the US given the region is diversifying. Speaking exclusively to the ABC’s Global Affairs Editor Laura Tingle in Kuala Lumpur, Prime Minister Ibrahim said he told US President Donald Trump that tariffs on his country are too high. He also spoke about the war in Gaza, saying leaders were blinded and practicing hypocrisy, in not supporting the Palestinian people. title: New AFP taskforce to target men 'hunting' young girls for violent acts | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian Federal Police have been working with Microsoft to develop AI tools to interpret Gen Z and Alpha slang to quickly identify children at risk of sadistic online exploitation.  New AFP Commissioner Krissy Barrett used her first speech at the National Press Club on Wednesday to announce the creation of Taskforce Pompilid, which will use the technology amongst a raft of measures to crack down on decentralised online crime networks.    The AFP is warning that young girls are being "hunted, stalked and drawn-in" by men using online networks to coerce them into carrying out serious acts of violence on themselves, their siblings or pets, in a "twisted type of gamification".  The Commissioner also offered practical steps to keep children out of harm's way.  "Let kids know they have the right to feel safe online and, if something feels uncomfortable, they can leave a chat at any time and tell a safe adult.   You can encourage safe conversations by talking regularly about online activities and apps, encouraging critical thinking, and reassuring kids that they won't be punished for coming forward if they think they have done something wrong.   Also, you can look out for warning signs that include self-harm, changes in eating or sleeping habits, sudden withdrawal from friends, families or activities, use of extreme behaviour, extreme language or symbols, and rejection of previously held morals.   Importantly, there are really practical and easy resources available, including how to make a report about child exploitation, at the AFP-led Australian Centre to Counter Child Exploitation website. That's www.acce.gov.au". she said.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: How did Tasmania's Spirit ferry operator make a $9 million mistake? | ABC NEWS
description: A multi-million-dollar blunder in the delivery of Tasmania's long-awaited Bass Strait ferries was revealed this week in a parliamentary hearing.  The day before the hearing, the government also let drop that a $75 million equity injection for state-owned ship operator TT-Line was needed.  Delays, cost blowouts and bureaucratic stuff ups have plagued the deliver of the two new ferries, which are expected to be in service by October 2026, as Josh Duggan reports.
